pros: Amazing colleagues who are passionate about their work, great student body dedicated to social justice, beautiful setting in the Swannanoa Valley just outside Asheville
cons: As many small liberal arts colleges are encountering, resources can be scarce.

pros: The atmosphere (people and place), mission, values are great
cons: Low pay, little help towards retirement, resulting in high turnover and everyone being short staffed.

pros: Great community atmosphere, environmentally responsible, good coworkers.
cons: Low pay, not much room for advancement, employee base turns over somewhat regularly.

pros: Open and honest community with students who come from very different backgrounds yet find common ground at WWC. I enjoyed being a student at WWC and would recommend that others pursue an education from Warren Wilson college.
cons: I do not have any cons about Warren Wilson other than creating more spaces for students to enjoy the college resources. I find that a lot of WWC resources are unknown to most students and therefore are overlooked and not used as much as they should be.

pros: The mission of the college is amazing and the students are great.
cons: Lack of confidence in folks at the very top (President, Board, CFO).

review_title: Fun job, but they should pay student employees a real paycheck

pros: Warren Wilson College provides an easy-going, laid back work atmosphere with a lot of opportunities to maintain a healthy work-life balance.
cons: The college has come to a pinnacle point in her history. A lot of restructuring has people feeling anxious, the leadership is weak, turnover rates are high, and almost the entire administration has been replaced. The feelings of tension and anxiety on campus are inescapable. Hopefully, the college as an institution is about to break through to something great, but that is the best-case scenario. Likely, the school will continue to stay stagnant, despite ongoing operational and administrative changes. Steve Solnick is a traditionalist and hardly a visionary. He will keep the school afloat, but I don't see him having what it takes to restore Warren Wilson to the progressive leader in sustainable higher education that it has been in the past.

pros: Fine hours, work isnt too hard

job_title: Admissions Office Tour Guide in Asheville, NC
pros: Loved working in the Admissions office. Mostly everyone is friendly. Being that I was a student athlete at the college, they worked with me closely to make sure I was learning a lot from the job while also staying true to my student athlete title.
cons: Some of the management were a bit over reactive towards students. High turn over rate. Low diversity. Poor professionalism when working with perspective athletes. More attention to detail would help.

pros: You will never find a more beautiful setting to work.  There were a ton of perks including yoga classes, free raw milk, organic veggie sales, concerts, massages, hiking trails, and they gave a 10% contribution to employees 3%.
cons: Salary could have been improved.  The college seems to be in a constant state of financial hardship, raises were frozen for several years.

pros: Some of the best people to work with in the world. The students are not bad either.The location is great!
cons: The school will not accept change very well. The Students are rather stuck in their ways. The budget will not allow you to be very creative.

pros: Work/life balance, often busy, friendly and understanding employer/work crew leader
cons: Work crew leader was often missing, sometimes customers were rude, other employees left without direction, poor communication as a whole

pros: Friendly staff and beautiful location in Black Mountain, North Carolina.
cons: In my position there was no real room for advancement.
